title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Such was the passing of Percival Reed, Keeper of Redesdale, who tookwith him, when at length he relinquished his charge, a humble henchman,a hind of the Rede Valley.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The men would uncover their heads and bow as theypassed, and the Keeper of Redesdale, courteous in the spirit as in thebody, would punctiliously return their salutations.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Still the Keeper of Redesdale was Percival Reed.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Five miles of land did that disembodied spirit of the Keeper ofRedesdale choose for his own.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The folk ofRedesdale bore it until they could bear it no longer.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Strong spirit from the Low Countries might begood jumping powder for the Keeper of Redesdale, but it was a dampingpotion for the keeper's musket when gently poured on its priming.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The appointed night came, and erethey started in the uncertain light of a misty moon the keeper ofRedesdale supped at Girsonfield.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Percival Reed would have to get his leave, or it was allup with reiving in Redesdale.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: There came at last a day, when no raids were afoot, when Hall met someof the Crozier clan, and opinions were frankly expressed with regard tothe keeper of Redesdale.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Now it must have seemed to Hall of Girsonfield, the head of the chief ofthe northern clans, a very clear error in judgment for any of the powersthat existed to pass him over and appoint as keeper of Redesdale hisfriend and neighbour, Percival Reed.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: In the sixteenth century one of the most powerful of the clans in thewild Northumbrian country was that of the Reeds of Redesdale.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: I have seen the genuine breed     long ago at Ned Dunn's of the Whitelee at the head of     Redesdale.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: I have seen the genuine breed     long ago at Ned Dunn's of the Whitelee at the head of     Redesdale.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Fox, bishop of Durham (1495), complains that dissolute and uncanonical priests administered the rites and sacraments of the holy church to the Tyne and Redesdale moss-troopers and murderers.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: If their own side of the Tweed promised a better or an easier raid, the borderer gave it the preference — but the moss-troopers  in Tynedale and Redesdale were unscrupulous, and did not hesitate to take liberties with the sacred property of mother Church, bundling ofl^ the beeves of Hugh Pudsy, bishop of Durham — one of the most pugnacious priests in Britain ; and a prelate, according to general consent,  reputed to be second to none in his day at anathematizing a sinner.

title: Horae subsecivae.
author: Brown, John
snippet: I have seen the genuine breed long ago at Ned Dunn's of the Whitelee at the head of Redesdale.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Scottish clans of the middle marchesarrived in arms and in attendance upon Sir JohnCarmichael of Carmichael; and, from the oppositeside, the Borderers of Tynedale and Redesdaleadvanced, with " jack and spear and bended bows,"with Sir John Forster, the English warden.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Moreover, they are enjoined, when theyshall enter any church, chapel, or cemetery in theterritory of Redesdale or Tynedale, to lay aside,upon their entrance, every offensive weapon exceeding one cubit in length, and to hold speechwith no one while within these hallowed precincts,excepting the curate or ministering priest of thesaid church or chapel, all under penalty of thegreater excommunication.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: It would seem that the opposite valleys of Redesdale and Tynedale were better supplied with persons (such as they were) who took upon them thecharacter of churchmen.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The men of Tynedaleand Redesdale, in particular, appear to have beenmore frequently tempted by the rich vales of theBishopric of Durham, and other districts which layto the southward, than by the rude desolation ofthe Scottish hills.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Hexham, in the centre of the Borderline, was also fortified, so that if any considerablebody of the Scottish forces should penetratethrough the wastes of Redesdale and Tynedale,they might still find an obstacle in their passage.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In the station of Habitancum,now called Risingham, near the village of Woodbourn in Redesdale, was found a Roman altardedicated to Mogon, a god of the Gadeni; andthere is one in the Advocates' Library of Edinburgh inscribed to the Did Campestres, or Fairies.
